{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Use British English|date=August 2017}} {{good article}} {{Infobox person | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100|OBE}} | name = Sarah Lancashire | image = Sarah Lancashire 2013.jpg | caption = Lancashire at the [[2013 British Academy Television Awards]] | birth_name = Sarah-Jane Abigail Lancashire | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|10|10|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Oldham]], [[Lancashire]], England | occupation = [[Actress]] | known for = [[Sarah Lancashire filmography|List of credits]] | years_active = 1987–present | relatives = [[Geoffrey Lancashire]]
{{small|(father)}} | spouse = {{marriage|[[Peter Salmon (producer)|Peter Salmon]]|2001}} | children = 3 | awards = [[List of awards and nominations received by Sarah Lancashire|Full list]] }} '''Sarah-Jane Abigail Lancashire''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|OBE}} (born 10 October 1964) is an English actress from [[Oldham]], [[Lancashire]]. She graduated from the [[Guildhall School of Music and Drama]] in 1986 and began her career in local theatre, whilst teaching drama classes at the [[University of Salford]]. Lancashire found popular success in television programmes including ''[[Coronation Street]]'' (1991–1996, 2000), ''[[Where the Heart Is (UK TV series)|Where the Heart Is]]'' (1997–1999), ''[[Clocking Off]]'' (2000) and ''Seeing Red'' (2000) and earned widespread recognition. In the summer of 2000, Lancashire signed a two-year [[golden handcuffs]] contract with [[ITV (TV network)|the ITV network]] which made her the UK's highest paid television actress. Subsequent television roles include the [[costume drama]]s [[Oliver Twist (2007 TV miniseries)|''Oliver Twist'']] (2007), ''[[Lark Rise to Candleford]]'' (2008–2011) and ''[[The Paradise (TV series)|The Paradise]]'' (2012), and the fact based dramas ''[[Cherished (film)|Cherished]]'' (2005) and ''[[Five Daughters]]'' (2010). Since 2012, Lancashire has earned extensive critical acclaim for her roles in the contemporary drama series ''[[Last Tango in Halifax]]'' (2012–2016) and ''[[Happy Valley (TV series)|Happy Valley]]'' (2014–present). Lancashire has also appeared in the feature films ''[[And When Did You Last See Your Father?]]'' (2007) and ''[[Dad's Army (2016 film)|Dad's Army]]'' (2016), and [[West End theatre]] productions including ''[[Blood Brothers (musical)|Blood Brothers]]'' in 1990, ''[[Guys and Dolls]]'' from 2005 to 2006 and ''[[Betty Blue Eyes]]'' in 2011. Her combined acting credits have earned Lancashire a [[List of awards and nominations received by Sarah Lancashire|number of awards and nominations]] over a career spanning four decades, including two [[British Academy Television Award]] wins out of five nominations. She was appointed an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the [[2017 Birthday Honours]] for services to drama. ==Life and career (20th century)== ===Early life and career beginnings (1964–1990)=== Sarah-Jane Abigail Lancashire{{London Gazette|issue=61962|supp=y|page=B12|date=17 June 2017}} was born on 10 October 1964 in [[Oldham]], [[Lancashire]].{{cite web|url=http://www.examiner.co.uk/whats-on/happy-valley-tv-series-spotlight-7141810|title=Happy Valley: Spotlight on Sarah Lancashire|work=[[Huddersfield Daily Examiner]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=Robinson|first=Samantha|date=20 May 2014|accessdate=21 May 2014}} Her father, [[Geoffrey Lancashire]] (1933–2004), was a television scriptwriter noted for his work on the soap opera ''[[Coronation Street]]'' and [[situation comedy|situation comedies]] such as ''[[The Cuckoo Waltz]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2014-04-29/sarah-lancashire-on-happy-valley-im-my-own-harshest-critic|title=Sarah Lancashire on Happy Valley: I'm my own harshest critic|work=[[Radio Times]]|publisher=[[Immediate Media Company]]|last=Duncan|first=Andrew|date=29 April 2014|accessdate=20 May 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/nov/08/guardianobituaries.broadcasting1|title=Geoffrey Lancashire|last=Purser|first=Philip|date=8 November 2004|accessdate=24 June 2015|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]}} Her mother, Hilda, worked as Geoffrey's personal assistant. She has three brothers, one her elder, one younger and a twin.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Interview%3A+Sarah+Lancashire%3A+I'm+Mum+first...%3B+SARAH+LANCASHIRE+MADE...-a060960847|title=Interview: Sarah Lancashire: I'm Mum first...; Sarah Lancashire made her name in ''Coronation Street'' and is rarely off our screens. But to her, the most important role she plays is as mother to two young sons. She talks to Annie Leask|work=[[Sunday Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=Leask|first=Annie|date=5 March 2000|accessdate=20 May 2014}} Lancashire was educated at [[Oldham Hulme Grammar School]] between 1976-81.{{cite web|url=http://www.hulme-grammar.oldham.sch.uk/alumni/|title=Alumni|work=''www.hulme-grammar.oldham.sch.uk''|publisher=[[Oldham Hulme Grammar School]]|accessdate=18 November 2014}} At the age of 17, she started to suffer from [[clinical depression]].{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/i-havent-slept-for-14-months-and-i-cant-1599731|title=I haven't slept for 14 month and I can't pack in Smoking.. but I love being a mum|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=4 June 2004|accessdate=24 November 2014}} Lancashire has stated she was never driven by the ideas of fame and status. Her background had inspired an initial interest in working behind the scenes in television. She did not give serious thought to the performing arts until the age of 18.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Mirror+Works%3A+My+CV%3A+Sarah+Lancashire%3A+Streets+ahead%3B+FORGET+RAQUEL,...-a0118828905|title=Mirror Works: My CV: Sarah Lancashire: Streets ahead; Forget Raquel, this lady is tough|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=Lancashire|first=Sarah|date=1 July 2004|accessdate=20 May 2014}} After winning a place at the [[Guildhall School of Music and Drama]], Lancashire realised that she enjoyed acting. She graduated in 1986, describing her time as a student there as "tremendous" but "seriously hard work and quite intimidating".{{cite web|url=http://www.gsmd.ac.uk/about_the_school/alumni/people_who_studied_at_guildhall/acting_graduates_test/sarah_lancashire/|work=Guildhall School of Music and Drama|title=Sarah Lancashire|accessdate=20 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140518190307/http://www.gsmd.ac.uk/about_the_school/alumni/people_who_studied_at_guildhall/acting_graduates_test/sarah_lancashire/|archivedate=18 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} After rejection from several [[repertory theatre]] companies, Lancashire was given her first acting role by Howard Lloyd-Lewis, artistic director of the [[Manchester Central Library#Library Theatre|Manchester Library Theatre Company]], which provided her with an [[Equity Card]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2004/jun/12/careers.graduates6|title=My first boss|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=12 June 2004|accessdate=21 May 2014|last=Iziren|first=Adeline}} Lancashire performed two plays with the company, ''[[Pacific Overtures]]'' and ''The Beauty Game'', which she states formed "the start of my career as an actor".{{cite web|url=http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/leisure/whats_on/11207791.Sarah_Lancashire_urges_local_people___Take_a_walk_to_your_theatre___please__/?ref=rss|title=Sarah Lancashire urges local people: "Take a walk to your theatre — please!"|work=[[The Westmorland Gazette]]|publisher=[[Newsquest]]|date=17 May 2014|accessdate=21 May 2014}} She found her first professional acting experience "terrifying" as a result of the live audiences, recalling that, "because I wore a bathing costume in some of the scenes, I got heckled!" She also realised that taking risks or underperforming could have had consequences for her acting career. Her role as Denise in ''The Beauty Game'' earned her a nomination for Best Supporting Actress at the [[Manchester Evening News Theatre Awards]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independenttalent.com/actors/sarah-lancashire/|title=Sarah Lancashire|work=Independenttalent.com|publisher=[[Duncan Heath#Independent Talent Group|Independent Talent Group]]|accessdate=23 May 2017}} At the age of 22, Lancashire married her first serious boyfriend, Gary Hargreaves, a music lecturer 11 years her senior, whom she had met four years earlier. Recalling the circumstances of her first marriage in 2001, Lancashire stated she only married because she became pregnant and possessed both a traditional outlook and a fear of the stigma of having a child out of wedlock. Thomas, her first child with Hargreaves, was born in 1987; a second son, Matthew, was born in 1989. During her early career, Lancashire found herself with large breaks between theatre appearances. To support herself financially, she worked as a drama teacher for five years at [[Salford University]] alongside her acting work.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/real-lives-she-refuses-to-be-photographed-out-of-character-and-is-always-on-her-guard-against-those-who-would-make-raquel-a-figure-of-fun-joining-coronation-street-really-is-like-joining-the-royal-family-1597017.html|title=Real Lives: She refuses to be photographed out of character, and is always on her guard against those who would make Raquel a figure of fun. Joining Coronation Street really is like joining the Royal Family|last=Thompson|first=Ben|date=20 August 1995|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Limited|accessdate=21 May 2014|location=London, England}} Discussing Lancashire's time as a visiting lecturer in Acting and Characterisation, Professor Ron Cook, Head of the University's School of Media, Music and Performance, noted that Lancashire made a "significant impact" in the formative stages of the drama department at the University and had also directed student productions.{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/actress-wins-degree-of-recognition-1167470|title=Actress wins degree of recognition|work=[[Manchester Evening News]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|location=Manchester|date=13 March 2002|accessdate=29 June 2012}} In 1987, Lancashire made a brief appearance in ''[[Coronation Street]]'' as Wendy Farmer, a prospective lodger of series regular [[Jack Duckworth]] ([[Bill Tarmey]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Lancashire+hot+spots!%3B+ONCE+CORONATION+STREET'S+MOST+FAMOUS+BARMAID,...-a060807002|title=Lancashire hot spots!; Once Coronation Street's most famous barmaid, Sarah Lancashire is set to star in a gritty new drama for the BBC|work=[[Coventry Evening Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=McMullen|first=Marion|date=22 January 2000|accessdate=21 May 2014}} In the late 1980s, she also appeared in an episode of the [[children's television|children's]] [[anthology series]] ''[[Dramarama]]'', and a single episode of the ITV sitcom ''[[Watching]]''.{{cite episode|title=Joking|series=Watching|credits=Les Chatfield(director)|network=ITV|airdate=1 December 1989|number=1|seriesno=4}} In 1990, Lancashire received her "big break" — the role of Linda in a production of [[Willy Russell]]'s ''[[Blood Brothers (musical)|Blood Brothers]]'' at the [[Noël Coward Theatre|Albery Theatre]]. Although she thoroughly enjoyed performing in [[West end theatre|London's West End]], she found it difficult to reconcile the experience with raising two young children in Manchester.{{cite web|url=http://london.broadway.com/buzz/156460/sarah-lancashire-on-co-starring-with-a-beautiful-pig-in-londons-betty-blue-eyes/|title=Sarah Lancashire on Co-Starring with a Beautiful Pig in London's Betty Blue Eyes|last=Wolf|first=Matt|date=18 May 2011|accessdate=21 May 2014|publisher=Broadway.com}} ===Breakthrough and popular success (1991–2000)=== [[File:Rovers Return tour.jpg|thumb|The ''Coronation Street'' set, pictured in 2005. Lancashire appeared in the serial for five years between 1991 and 1996]] Two weeks after finishing her run in ''Blood Brothers'', Lancashire auditioned for the role of new ''Coronation Street'' character [[Raquel Wolstenhulme]], a colleague of supermarket employee [[Curly Watts]] ([[Kevin Kennedy (actor)|Kevin Kennedy]]).{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/article2404086.ece|title=Just a doll from the Street|last=Maxwell|first=Dominic|date=21 November 2005|newspaper=[[The Times]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|accessdate=6 February 2011|location=London, England}} Lancashire joined on a three-month contract, continuing to teach at Salford University for another year.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/article213160.ece|title=Interview: The great pretender|last=Kinnes|first=Sally|date=29 December 2002|work=[[The Times]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|accessdate=21 May 2014|location=London, England|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141104222448/http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/article213160.ece|archivedate=4 November 2014}} Raquel first appeared on 25 January 1991 and departed on 10 May; having moved to London to try to launch a modelling career.{{cite episode|title=Episode 3179|series=[[Coronation Street]]|credits=[[John R. Stevenson|John Stevenson]] (writer), [[Richard Signy]] (director), [[Mervyn Watson]] (producer)|network=[[ITV1]]|airdate=25 January 1991}}{{cite episode|title=Episode 3224|series=[[Coronation Street]]|credits=[[John Stevenson (scriptwriter)|John Stevenson]] (writer), David Richards (director), [[Mervyn Watson]] (producer)|airdate=10 May 1991}} Lancashire had initially been reserved about Raquel's characterisation, noting that her "acidic side" could have rendered her the "street bitch" had it been embellished. She took care to highlight Raquel's potential, playing against what had been written to make her more comic, evoking audience sympathy. Between 26 September and 19 October 1991, Lancashire played the title role in an adaption of ''[[Educating Rita]]'' at the [[Queen's Theatre, Hornchurch]].{{cite web|url=http://www.queens-theatre.co.uk/archive/educatingrita1991.htm|title=26 September – 19 October Educating Rita|publisher=[[Queen's Theatre, Hornchurch]]|accessdate=21 May 2014}} Following Raquel's reintroduction on 30 December 1991,{{cite episode|title=Episode 3325|series=[[Coronation Street]]|credits=[[Phil Woods]] (writer), David Richards (director), [[Mervyn Watson]] (producer)|airdate=30 December 1991}} Lancashire committed herself to ''Coronation Street'' full-time. She would remain in the series until 1996, earning a reported annual salary of £90,000.{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111317714.html|title=Hankies out for Raquel's EastEnding; Street's week-long tearjerker signals fightback in soap war|last=Busfield|first=Steve|date=9 November 1996|work=[[Daily Mail]]|publisher=[[Associated Newspapers]]|accessdate=5 January 2011}} Two years into the role, she experienced a 14-month [[nervous breakdown]] but did not confide in anyone besides her close family or take any time off work, which in retrospect she deemed "the worst thing [she] could have done.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/otr..Off+The+Record:+Gavin+leaves+them+Bushed.-a060857451|title=Off The Record: Gavin leaves them Bushed.|last=Fulton|first=Rick|last2=Dingwall|first2= John |date=13 March 2000|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|accessdate=6 February 2011|location=Glasgow, Scotland}} During the worst part of her experience Lancashire described herself as "hysterical at the thought of getting out of bed".{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/mum-s-the-word-1-536672|title=Mum's the word|work=The Scotsman|publisher=[[Johnston Press]]|date=25 June 2004|accessdate=9 December 2014}} Her mother Hilda forced her to seek medical assistance for her condition, which Lancashire states "gave me my life back", her twenties having been "a write-off".{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/celebrity-on-the-couch-40-faces-of-depression-in-the-spotlight-419167.html|title=Celebrity on the couch: 40 faces of depression in the spotlight|last=Owen|first=Jonathan|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Media Group|date=8 October 2006|accessdate=9 December 2014}} Lancashire felt her first marriage had also contributed to her unhappiness; in 2001, she stated that though her marriage lasted ten years, it "was 10 years longer than it should have done". In 1995 she separated from Hargeaves; the pair would ultimately later divorce. She described leaving her marriage as a "cleansing experience" and a "renaissance"; one that enabled her to rediscover her sense of identity. Other steps that Lancashire took to combat her depression included remaining single for five years, attending therapy sessions, and taking prescriptions of the anti-depressant drug [[Paroxetine]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/4723457/It-has-all-been-a-bit-bloody-tricky.html|title=It has all been a bit bloody tricky|last=Moir|first=Jan|date=11 May 2001|accessdate=10 December 2014|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]}} In December 1995 Lancashire starred in the spin-off straight-to-video film ''[[Coronation Street home video releases#The Cruise|Coronation Street – The Cruise]]'', a 75-minute special detailing Raquel and Curly's honeymoon. The special was advertised as being exclusive to video, and 750,000 copies were sold, to the value of £10 million.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/street-cruises-for-fall-over-videos-brief-honeymoon-1304046.html|title='Street' cruises for fall over video's brief honeymoon|last=MacDonald|first=Marianne|date=10 April 1996|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Limited|accessdate=6 February 2011|location=London, England}} Lancashire departed ''Coronation Street'' in 1996 due to her heavy work schedule and desire to pursue other projects.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/536542.stm|title=Raquel's Corrie comeback|date=25 November 1999|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=5 January 2011}} She had also tired of the fame the role brought her, shying away from personal appearances and interviews with television magazines.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/streetwise-728228.html|title=Streetwise|last=Ross|first=Deborah|date=24 January 2000|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Limited|accessdate=6 February 2011|location=London, England}} Her final scenes attracted 20 million viewers. Lancashire's performance in the role saw her nominated in the Most Popular Actress category at the [[2nd National Television Awards]] in October 1996.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Here's+to+a+win+for+Raquel.-a061286902|title=Here's to a win for Raquel|last=Wallace|first=Robert|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=5 October 1996|accessdate=21 May 2014}} Lancashire's next role was [[district nurse]] Ruth Goddard in the ITV drama series ''[[Where the Heart Is (UK TV series)|Where the Heart Is]]'', which began airing in 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/LAST+NIGHT%3B+Chiller+that+gets+to+heart+of+the+matter.-a061019502|title=Last Night; Chiller that gets to heart of the matter|last=Millar|first=John|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=7 April 1997|accessdate=21 May 2014}} Also in 1997 she filmed a [[situation comedy]] for the BBC, ''[[Bloomin' Marvellous]]'', in which she played Liz, one half of an argumentative married couple trying for a baby.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/northern-exposure-1246789.html|title=Northern Exposure|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Limited|date=23 August 1997|accessdate=21 May 2013|first=Rampton|last=James}} However, due to poor viewing figures and a damning critical response the sitcom was not renewed.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/A+bloomin'+flop's+axed.-a061066544|title=A bloomin' flop's axed|last=Hughes|first=Chris|work=[[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=29 November 1997|accessdate=21 May 2014}} Regarding the negative reception to the series, her co-star [[Clive Mantle]] saracastically remarked "I've seen murderers and rapists get a better press than we did".{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-81463430.html|title=In the Frame– Clive Mantle; Sunday|work=[[Liverpool Daily Post]], Liverpool, accessed via [[HighBeam Research]]|date=5 January 2002|accessdate=27 March 2013}} Lancashire continued to star as Ruth Goddard in ''Where the Heart Is'' for its second and third series in 1998 and 1999. In 1998 she was nominated for her second National Television Award for Most Popular Actress.{{cite web|title=Viewers' favourites to be revealed|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/202484.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=12 November 2010|date=27 October 1998}} In February 1999 she made a guest appearance in the [[British dark comedy]] anthology series ''[[Murder Most Horrid]]'' alongside comedian [[Dawn French]]. The pair played two yachtswoman whose journey ends with fatal repercussions.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/PICK+OF+THE+BOX%3B+It's+all+a+bit+too+fishy+for+Seattle's+finest.-a060427451|title=Pick of the box; It's all a bit too fishy for Seattle's finest|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=26 February 1999|accessdate=21 May 2014}} In April it was announced that Lancashire would be quitting ''Where the Heart Is'', despite an offered pay rise. At the time, ''Where the Heart is'' was the third most popular drama on British Television, regularly attracting 12 million viewers. Lancashire's decision was reportedly influenced by the series filming away from home, and a fear that remaining in the series long term would harm her career.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SARAH%3A+MY+HEART+ISN'T+IN+IT%3B+Homesick+star+quits+show.-a060394607|title=Sarah: My heart isn't in it; Homesick star quits show|date=30 April 1999|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=Graham|first=Polly|accessdate=21 May 2014}} In January 2000 she expanded on her decision, stating that Ruth "was too chocolate-boxy, no longer a challenge".{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Interview+Sarah+Lancashire%3A+Conquering+my+secret+fears%3B+Sarah...-a060281806|title=Interview Sarah Lancashire: Conquering my secret fears; Sarah Lancashire walked out on two hit shows at the peak of her fame without harming her popularity, but only now is she starting to believe in herself|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=8 January 2000|accessdate=21 May 2014|last=Kingsley|first=Hilary}} On 2 January 2000, Lancashire returned to ''Coronation Street'' for a single episode in which Raquel asks Curly for a divorce. Lancashire felt it was an apt time to return, as she was now a more confident actress and wanted to portray Raquel again before she aged significantly. The series' producer at the time, [[Jane Macnaught]], deemed Raquel one of ''Coronation Street''{{'s}} most popular ever characters and her return an opportunity for her "millions of fans" to learn what had become of her. Lancashire and Kennedy were the sole actors in the episode, the first to feature just two characters.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/features/fifty-things-you-didnt-know-about-the-street-2155003.html|title=Fifty things you didn't know about The Street|last=Viner|first=Brian|date=9 December 2010|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Limited|accessdate=22 May 2014|location=London, England}} From late January, Lancashire appeared as factory employee Yvonne Kolakowski, a widow with a dysfunctional personal life, in the [[BBC One]] drama series ''[[Clocking Off]]''. Lancashire used her own experiences as a single mother in her characterisation. In March, she played actress [[Coral Atkins]] in the [[television film]] ''Seeing Red''.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SUNDAY+TV%3A+HIGHLIGHTS.-a060802354|title=Sunday TV: Highlights|work=[[Coventry Evening Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=McMullen|first=Marion|date=18 March 2000|accessdate=22 May 2014}} Lancashire found shooting the drama, which detailed Atkins' decision to quit her acting career in order to set up a care home for abused children, "mentally draining". Lancashire then spent eight weeks filming the BBC One legal sitcom ''[[Chambers (sitcom)|Chambers]]'' in which she played "ambitious" and "bigoted" barrister Ruth Quirke.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Ditherer+has+a+brush+with+law%3B+Actor+James+Fleet+specialises+in+men...-a062673762|title=Ditherer has a brush with law; Actor James Fleet specialises in men who wouldn't say boo to a goose. New BBC1 sitcom Chambers has him looking ruffled and defenceless in a court of law, and it suits him. Graham Keal reports.|last=Keal|first=Graham|work=[[The Birmingham Post]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=10 June 2000|accessdate=22 May 2014}} The series was aired from June 2000. Lancashire's final role in 2000 was in the two-part drama thriller ''My Fragile Heart''.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/TV%3A+Sarah+Plays+It+From+The+Heart.-a065262789|title=TV: Sarah Plays It From The Heart|work=[[The Sunday People]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=17 September 2000|accessdate=22 May 2014}} Lancashire's output in 2000 earned her several awards. She was voted best actress at the [[TV Quick]] Awards in September 2000 for her roles in ''Clocking Off'' and ''Seeing Red'', and in October was voted Most Popular Actress at the [[6th National Television Awards]] for ''Seeing Red''.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/910246.stm|title=Ali G takes top TV award|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=4 September 2000|accessdate=22 May 2014}}{{cite web|title=National Television Awards: The winners|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/966147.stm|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=12 November 2010|date=10 October 2000}} In March 2001 she was named Drama Performer of the Year by the [[Television and Radio Industries Club]], with mention of her work in ''Clocking Off'' and ''Seeing Red''.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/1218732.stm|title=Robinson booed at awards|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=11 March 2001|accessdate=22 May 2014}} ==Life and career (21st century)== ==="Golden Handcuffs" contract=== [[File:Peter Salmon at Nations & Regions Media Conference cropped.jpg|200px|thumb|Lancashire's husband, the television executive [[Peter Salmon (producer)|Peter Salmon]], pictured in 2012]] Following Lancashire's success in connecting with a television audience, ITV sought to secure her exclusively to their network in a two-year golden handcuffs deal, which was finalised in July 2000.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/841499.stm|title=ITV signs up Lancashire|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=19 July 2000|accessdate=22 May 2014}} Lancashire became the first actress to be given such a contract with ITV.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Golden+girl+Sarah+sticks+to+ITV+parts.-a063586832|title=Golden girl Sarah sticks to ITV parts|work=[[Coventry Evening Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=20 July 2000|accessdate=22 May 2014}} The deal, worth £1.3 million, made Lancashire the highest-paid actress in British Television.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/1505624.stm|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|title=Street star Sarah weds|date=23 August 2001|accessdate=22 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Life's+murder+after+a+soap%3B+The+long+road+back+to+fame+takes...-a076003006|title=Life's murder after a soap; The long road back to fame takes EastEnders stars from Albert Square to wet, windy Blackpool|work=[[Sunday Mail (Scotland)|Sunday Mail]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=4 February 2001|accessdate=22 May 2014|last=Hendry|first=Steve}} Discussing the exclusive signing ITV controller of drama Nick Elliott identified Lancashire as being someone with "a great range [who] creates a tremendous empathy with an audience". He also admitted that heavy interest in Lancashire from the BBC had been a factor in giving her the contract, and blocking her from working with other networks.{{cite web|url=http://observer.theguardian.com/screen/story/0,6903,345884,00.html|title=We can't get enough of TV's famous five|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|last=Ogle|first=Tina|date=23 July 2000|accessdate=25 June 2015}} Her last role on BBC One during this period was comedy drama ''Gentleman's Relish'', an adaptation of the [[Miles Gibson]] novel ''[[Kingdom Swann]]''. The television film, which aired on New Year's Day 2001, was Lancashire's first in the [[costume drama]] genre; she played a housekeeper harbouring romantic feelings for her employer ([[Billy Connolly]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/How+The+Grinch+stole+the+budget+for+Christmas+TV%3B+Christmas+TV...-a083099466|title=How The Grinch stole the budget for Christmas TV; Christmas TV Preview|work=[[Sunday Mail (Scotland)|Sunday Mail]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=Hendry|first=Steve|date=17 December 2000|accessdate=22 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Big+Yin's+Corrie-on+comedy+with+TV+barmaid.-a065128517|title=Big Yin's Corrie-on comedy with TV barmaid|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=McGivern|first=Mark|date=11 September 2000|accessdate=22 May 2014}} Her first role under her new contract with ITV was the six-part drama ''The Glass'' opposite [[John Thaw]]. The series, which aired between May and June 2001 saw Lancashire star as a saleswoman for a double-glazing company who ends up caught in a [[love triangle]] with her boss and his nephew.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/WEEKEND+TV%3A+SUNDAY+TV%3A+TODAY'S+HIGHLIGHTS.-a075076602|title=Weekend TV: Sunday TV: Today's Highlights|work=[[Coventry Evening Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=McMullen|first=Marion|date=26 May 2001|accessdate=22 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SUNDAY+TV%3A+TODAY'S+HIGHLIGHTS.-a076125654|title=Sunday TV: Today's Highlights|work=[[Coventry Evening Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=McMullen|first=Marion|date=30 June 2001|accessdate=22 May 2014}} Retrospectively, the series was judged not to be a success; it averaged 5.8 million viewers, less than rival show on [[BBC One]], ''[[Messiah (TV series)|Messiah]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-125234/ITV-unlocks-Sarahs-handcuffs.html|title=ITV unlocks Sarah's handcuffs|work=[[Daily Mail]]|publisher=[[DMG Media]]|last=Conlan|first=Tara|accessdate=22 May 2014}} In August 2001, Lancashire married television executive [[Peter Salmon (producer)|Peter Salmon]], in a low-key ceremony held at [[Langar Hall]], Nottinghamshire. Salmon had proposed to Lancashire in New York during a holiday at Easter time 2001. The two began a romantic relationship in the summer of 2000, though they had first met several years earlier whilst she was portraying Raquel on ''Coronation Street'' and he was employed by [[Granada Studios]], which produces the soap opera. In October Lancashire starred in an adaptation of the [[Michelle Magorian]] novel ''[[Back Home (novel)|Back Home]]'' as Peggy Dickinson, a woman adjusting to life in post-war Britain after having been separated from her family during the war.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/New+Queen+Vic%3B+Funny+girl+comes+top+of+the+pops.-a079321175|title=New Queen Vic; Funny girl comes top of the pops|work=[[Sunday Mail (Scotland)|Sunday Mail]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=21 October 2001|accessdate=22 May 2014}} In March 2002 Lancashire received an Honorary Master of Arts degree from Salford University.{{cite web|url=http://usir.salford.ac.uk/37036/|title=Sarah Lancashire, recipient of honorary degree|work=Library Archive|last=Forbes|first=SA|publisher=[[Salford University]]|location=Salford|date=12 November 2005|accessdate=30 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.starz.com/pressroomstatic/pr_thedresser/pdf/the_dresser_cast_biographies.pdf|title=The Dresser: Cast Biographies|author=Press Office|publisher=''[[Starz]]''|date=20 May 2016|accessdate=30 June 2017}} In April, She starred in two-part psychological thriller ''The Cry'', which she described as her "most naked role yet". She played a social worker grieving her second still-born child who is determined to protect a baby she perceives to be at risk of abuse.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Life's+good+for+Sarah+off+Street.-a084580796|title=Life's good for Sarah off Street|work=[[Liverpool Echo]]|date=8 April 2002|accessdate=22 May 2014}} Lancashire drew on her own experiences of [[clinical depression]] in her depiction of her character's mentality.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/My+own+depression+helped+to+bring+my+new+character+to+life%3B+Sarah's...-a084586244|title=My own depression helped to bring my new character to life; Sarah's experience of her darkest hours added realism to gritty new drama.|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=9 April 2002|accessdate=22 May 2014|last=Driscoll|first=Rob}} Her performance saw her awarded with a Golden Nymph award for Best Performance by an Actress in a Mini-Series at the [[Monte-Carlo Television Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tvfestival.com/pdfz/2002_palmares_uk.pdf|title=Festival de Television de Monte-Carlo 2002|date=8 September 2009}} In April it was reported that Lancashire had been lined up play the lead role in comedy drama ''[[Life Begins (TV series)|Life Begins]]'', which creator [[Mike Bullen]] had written with Lancashire in mind.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/apr/02/broadcasting|title=Cold Feet grows up|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=2 April 2002|last=Deans|first=Jason|accessdate=22 May 2012}} However, by June, Lancashire had exited the drama, unwilling to commit to a potentially long running series.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/jun/14/broadcasting1|title=Life Begins for ITV without Lancashire|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|last=Davies|first=Ashley|date=14 June 2002|accessdate=22 May 2014}} Later that month [[BBC News]] and newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that Lancashire had exited her exclusive deal with ITV, which would not be renewed after it expired in the autumn. The decision was reportedly influenced by Lancashire's desire to reduce her workload and to have the freedom to take on other roles.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/jun/27/broadcasting3|title=Lancashire casts off golden handcuffs|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|last=Deans|first=Jason|date=27 June 2002|accessdate=22 May 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/2069597.stm|title=Lancashire unlocks 'handcuffs' deal|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=27 June 2002|accessdate=22 May 2014}} In September 2002 she appeared in a two-part crime drama pilot, ''[[Rose and Maloney]]'', as legal investigator Rose Linden.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/TV+preview%3B+Sarah's+law+ITV's+golden+girl+Sarah+Lancashire+on+her...-a092208014|title=TV preview; Sarah's law ITV's golden girl Sarah Lancashire on her most complex character yet|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=Hendry|first=Steve|date=29 September 2012|accessdate=22 May 2013}} On 22 December she appeared in the television movie ''Birthday Girl'' as Rachel Jones, who plans a party to celebrate being in remission from a serious illness, only to discover that the disease has returned.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Sunday+tv+December+22%3A+Cold+call+for+Jack%3B+CRITIC'S+CHOICE.-a095691333|title=Sunday TV December 22: Cold call for Jack; Critic's Choice|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=21 December 2002|accessdate=22 May 2012}} Lancashire's final role under her ITV contract was Gertrude Morel in an adaptation of [[D.H. Lawrence]]'s 1913 novel ''[[Sons and Lovers]]'', airing in January 2003. The portrayal –her first of a mother with adult children– followed Gertrude's transformation from a young bride into a fifty-something woman ravaged by her life experiences of poverty and domestic abuse.{{cite web|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/HAVING+SEX+ON+THE+BOX+GAVE+ME+THE+GIGGLES%3B+Sarah+Lancashire+says+her...-a095246842|title=Having sex on the box gave me the giggles; Sarah Lancashire says her new role in Sons and Lovers left her blushing|last=Quinn|first=Thomas|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|date=12 December 2002|accessdate=30 June 2017}} Lancashire re-read the novel several times prior to filming, and identified with the themes of filial and marital relationships she had been unable to appreciate as a [[GCSE]] student. The miniseries gave her a sense of conviction in her career path, stating ahead of the broadcast in 2002: "whatever the reason I do what I do, I felt I had come to a point where I could stop searching after this". Reviewing the serial Paul Hoggart of ''[[The Times]]'' wrote that Lancashire "steals the show" with a "performance of immense subtlety and quiet strength, proof, if we still needed it, that she has matured into a terrific actress."{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/film/article2433647.ece|title=TV Review|newspaper=[[The Times]]|publisher=[[News UK]]|last=Hoggart|first=Paul|date=13 January 2003|accessdate=23 May 2014}} Conversely [[Andrew Billen]], writing in ''[[New Statesman]]'', wrote that "Sarah Lancashire was no revelation at all", purely because she had "long since proved herself a formidable actress".{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/node/156967|title=The Misery of Sex|last=Billen|first=Andrew|authorlink=Andrew Billen|work=[[New Statesman]]|date=20 January 2003|accessdate=30 June 2017}} === Subsequent projects (2004–2012) === [[File:Angela Cannings.jpg|thumb|200px|Lancashire portrayed [[Angela Cannings]] (pictured) in the 2005 television film ''[[Cherished (film)|Cherished]]'', a dramatisation of the activist's bereavement and subsequent wrongful imprisonment]] While pregnant with her third child, Lancashire began an 18-month career break, the longest of her working life.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+Box%3A+Future's+Rosy+for+Sarah%3B+Rose+And+Maloney+ITV1,+9pm,+Monday...-a0118945442|title=The Box: Future's Rosy for Sarah; Rose And Maloney ITV1, 9pm, Monday and Tuesday|work=[[Sunday Mercury]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=4 July 2005|accessdate=23 May 2014}} In April 2003, Lancashire gave birth to her third son, Joseph. Lancashire's first job after returning to work was her directorial debut on an episode of the BBC One anthology series ''[[The Afternoon Play]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/%60I+love+being+a+mum+again'.-a0118945215|title=I love being a mum again|last=Marlow|first=Will|work=[[Huddersfield Daily Examiner]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=2 July 2004|accessdate=23 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2003/09_september/29/afternoon_plays.shtml|title=Robson Green and Tina Hobley to star in second series of Afternoon Plays|work=BBC Press Office|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=29 September 2003|accessdate=23 May 2014}} For "Viva Las Blackpool" she was given the Best Newcomer Award (sponsored by [[BBC Birmingham]]) at the Birmingham Screen Festival and the Best New Talent Award at the [[Royal Television Society]] (Midlands) awards in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Art+awards%3A+Post+journalist+honoured+at+ceremony.-a0114152254|title=Art awards: Post journalist honoured at ceremony|last=Revill|first=John|work=[[The Birmingham Post]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|date=12 March 2004|accessdate=23 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2004/10_october/10/birmingham.shtml|title=BBC Birmingham dominates Royal Television Society awards|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=10 October 2004|accessdate=23 May 2014}} The venture also earned her first [[British Academy Television Awards]] nomination in 2005 for Best new Director of Fiction.{{cite web|url=http://awards.bafta.org/award/2005/tvcraft/new-director-fiction|title=Television Craft New Director — Fiction in 2005|publisher=[[BAFTA]]|accessdate=23 May 2012}} Lancashire next filmed three two-part stories for ''Rose and Maloney'', following on from the pilot episode in 2002. The delay between shooting for the pilot and its follow-up was a result of Lancashire's career break and problems reconciling her availability with that of co-star [[Phil Davis (actor)|Phil Davis]]. In 2005 Lancashire starred in ''[[The Rotters' Club (novel)#Adaptation|The Rotters' Club]]'' as a housewife in 1970s [[Birmingham]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Paddy+Shennan%3A+Rose-tinted+specs+on+the+city.-a0127904265|title=Paddy Shennan: Rose-tinted specs on the city|work=[[Liverpool Echo]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|last=Shennan|first=Paddy|date=26 January 2005|accessdate=23 May 2013}} Also in 2005 she appeared in the BBC television film ''[[Cherished (film)|Cherished]]'' as [[Angela Cannings]], a British woman who was wrongfully convicted of killing her two baby sons.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/drama/cherished/|title=Cherished|work=BBC Drama|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=23 May 2005}} Lancashire was proud to be involved with the project, having greatly admired Cannings strength of character during her ordeal, and being able to relate to her sense of anguish as a parent. Sally Wainwright and Sarah Lancashire reunite for Christmas special|last=Travis|first=Ben|work=[[Evening Standard]]|date=19 December 2016|accessdate=30 June 2017}} In 2014, Lancashire re-united with ''[[Last Tango in Halifax]]'' writer [[Sally Wainwright]] on the crime drama ''[[Happy Valley (TV series)|Happy Valley]]''. Wainwright was keen to write another role for Lancashire after being "blown away" by her performances in ''Last Tango in Halifax''.{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/happy-valley-sally-wainwright-most-7179526|title=Happy Valley: Writer Sally Wainwright on TV's most talked about show|work=[[Wales Online]]|last=Jones|first=Hannah|date=28 May 2014|accessdate=19 August 2014}} Lancashire portrays single-grandparent Catherine Cawood, a police sergeant still dealing with the aftermath of her daughter's rape, and subsequent suicide, eight years earlier. Mark Lawson of ''[[The Guardian]]'' identified the performance as a career best for Lancashire, stating that she perfectly conveyed "the script's demandingly contradictory notes of tragedy, comedy, love, guilt, weakness and courage".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/jun/03/happy-valley-end-of-series-tv-review-mark-lawson|title=Happy Valley TV review – Sarah Lancashire gives her best performance|newspaper=The Guardian|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=4 June 2014|accessdate=26 June 2015|last=Lawson|first=Mark}} For this role she earned the [[TV Choice Award]] for Best Actress in 2014,{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/s129/sherlock/news/a595419/sherlock-eastenders-lead-winners-at-tvchoice-awards-2014.html|title=Sherlock, EastEnders lead winners at TVChoice Awards 2014|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|last=Rigby|first=Sam|date=8 September 2014|accessdate=10 December 2014}} and the Royal Television Programme Award for Best Actress in 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/sarah-lancashire-tom-hollander-win-royal-television-society-programme-awards/|title=Sarah Lancashire and Tom Hollander win at Royal Television Society Programme Awards|work=[[The Stage]]|last=Hemley|first=Matthew|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=7 May 2015}} In September 2014 the ''[[Radio Times]]'' listed her as one of the thirty most powerful women in British television and radio.{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2014-09-02/the-radio-times-30-most-powerful-women-on-tv-and-radio|title=The ''Radio Times'' 30 most powerful women on TV and radio|work=[[Radio Times]]|date=2 September 2014|accessdate=26 February 2015}} In April 2015 she received her fourth BAFTA television nomination, her first in the [[British Academy Television Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] category.{{cite web|first=Alex|last= Ritman|title=BAFTA TV Awards: Benedict Cumberbatch Gets Third Nomination for 'Sherlock'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/bafta-tv-awards-benedict-cumberbatch-787198|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=8 April 2015|date=8 April 2015}} In June 2015 she was named Best Actress in a Drama Series at the [[Monte Carlo Television Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a653752/happy-valley-the-missing-and-lilyhammer-win-at-golden-nymph-awards.html|title=Happy Valley, The Missing and Lilyhammer win at Golden Nymph Awards|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|last=Harp|first=Justin|date=18 June 2015|accessdate=21 June 2015}} Despite Lancashire's concerns regarding the decision to extend the story told in ''Happy Valley'', Wainwright's "genuine" storytelling and "integrity" convinced her to return for a second series, which aired in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/news/sarah-lancashire-im-back-for-more-emotional-brutality-on-happy-valley-2-198070/|title=Sarah Lancashire: I'm back for more 'emotional brutality' on Happy Valley 2|work=''[[What's on TV]]''|last=Marland|first=Sean|date=4 February 2016|accessdate=2 May 2017}} Lancashire stated that she found the second series as "emotionally brutal" as the first; disclosing to ''The Independent'' that she inhabited Catherine's emotional pain for the entirety of the shoot.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/jan/26/happy-valley-realistic-tv-bbc-crime-drama-second-series|title=What makes Happy Valley TV's most realistic police drama?|work=[[The Independent]]|date=26 January 2016|accessdate=2 May 2017|last=Pidd|first=Helen}} Whilst promoting the second series, Lancashire also refuted criticism about the level of violence towards women in the series, stating she "would never condone anything which [she] thought was salacious, titillating, or gratuitous" and that Catherine's experience represented an "absolutely honest portrayal of what a female police officer can be subjected to". For her role in the second series of ''Happy Valley'', Lancashire won the [[22nd National Television Awards|2017 National Television Award]] for Best Dramatic Performance,{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/sarah-lancashire-nta-award-winner-happy-valley_uk_5889db4be4b0de43f92cde3f|title=Sarah Lancashire Collects A NTA Award – 8 Things You Didn't Know About 'Happy Valley' Star|work=Huffington Post|last=Frost|first=Caroline|date=26 January 2017|accessdate=2 May 2017}} and the BAFTA TV award for Best Actress.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/may/14/bbc-is-biggest-winner-at-baftas-as-happy-valley-and-damilola-head-award-roll-call|title=BBC biggest winner at Baftas as Happy Valley and Damilola head award roll call|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher= [[Guardian Media Group]]|date=14 May 2017|accessdate=15 May 2017|first=Hannah|last=Ellis-Petersen}} ===2015–present=== In March 2015 Lancashire began filming a [[The Dresser (2015 film)|television adaptation]] of [[Ronald Harwood]]{{'}}s 1980 play ''[[The Dresser]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2015/the-dresser|title=Production commences on The Dresser starring Anthony Hopkins and Ian McKellen|work=BBC Media Centre|date=3 March 2015|accessdate=5 March 2015}} In the teleplay, which aired in October 2015, Lancashire portrayed stage manager Madge, whose unrequited love for 'Sir' ([[Anthony Hopkins]]), the head of a repertory theatre company, pits her at odds with his dresser and confidant, Norman ([[Ian McKellen]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/mediapacks/thedresser/lancashire|title=The Dresser / Interview with Sarah Lancashire |publisher=BBC|date=21 October 2015|accessdate=2 November 2015}} Lancashire described ''The Dresser'' as "the greatest piece ever written about actors" and found both working with and observing McKellen and Hopkins – "two of the greatest actors ever" – an extraordinary experience. Following an airing on the American premium cable channel [[Starz]] in 2016, Lancashire was nominated for the 2016 [[Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Supporting Actress in a Movie/Miniseries|Critics' Choice Television Award for Best Supporting Actress in a Movie or Miniseries]] {{cite web|title=Critics' Choice TV Nominations Unveiled|url=http://deadline.com/2016/11/television-nominees-for-2016-critics-choice-awards-unveiled-1201853806/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|last=Lincoln|first=Ross|accessdate=17 May 2017|date=14 November 2016}} Lancashire played Mrs Pike in the 2016 feature film ''[[Dad's Army (2016 film)|Dad's Army]]'', based on the [[Dad's Army|situation comedy series of the same name]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/oct/08/catherine-zeta-jones-joins-cast-of-dads-army-film|title=She's in the army now: Catherine Zeta-Jones joins cast of Dad's Army film|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|last=Child|first=Ben|date=8 October 2014|accessdate=24 October 2014}} In early 2017, she began voicing the character of "Headmonstress" Mrs Twirlyhorn in the animated pre-school series ''School of Roars'', which airs on [[Cbeebies]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2017/school-of-roars|title=Top TV actors become monsters for new CBeebies animated series|publisher=BBC Press Office|date=24 January 2017|accessdate=17 May 2017}} Lancashire was due to appear opposite [[Martin Freeman]] in ''Labour of Love'', a political comedy by [[James Graham (playwright)|James Graham]], at the [[Noël Coward Theatre]] in late 2017{{cite web|url=https://www.londontheatre.co.uk/theatre-news/news/martin-freeman-and-sarah-lancashire-star-in-james-grahams-labour-of-love-at-the|title=Martin Freeman and Sarah Lancashire star in James Graham's Labour of Love at the Noel Coward Theatre|work=londontheatre.co.uk|date=19 May 2017|accessdate=19 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-4520896/Sarah-Lancashire-Martin-Freeman-stage-Labour-comeback.html|title=Sarah Lancashire and Martin Freeman stage a Labour comback... and there are 20,000 tickets up for grabs|last=Bamigboye|first=Baz|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=19 May 2017|accessdate=19 May 2017}} but pulled out on 1 September "on doctor's advice" and was replaced by [[Tamsin Greig]].{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2017/sarah-lancashire-pulls-james-grahams-labour-love/#_=_|title=Sarah Lancashire pulls out of James Graham's Labour of Love|work=thestage.co.uk|date=1 September 2017|accessdate=1 September 2017}} In 2018 she starred as Miriam –billed as an "experienced, no-nonsense social worker" – in ''[[Kiri (TV series)|Kiri]]'', a four-part drama series written by [[Jack Thorne]], co-produced by [[Channel 4]] and the American on-demand service [[Hulu]].{{cite web|url=https://inews.co.uk/essentials/happy-valleys-sarah-lancashire-star-channel-4-mixed-race-adoption-drama/|title=Happy Valley's Sarah Lancashire to star in Channel 4 mixed-race adoption drama|work=[[i (newspaper)|i]]|publisher=[[Johnston Press]]|location=[[London]]|last=Sherwin|first=Adam|date=6 July 2017|accessdate=6 July 2017}} The miniseries centres on a black girl living with a white foster couple who is murdered on a visit to her family, putting Miriam and the social services under scrutiny. ==Filmography== {{main|Sarah Lancashire filmography}} ==Awards and nominations== {{main|List of awards and nominations received by Sarah Lancashire}} Lancashire was appointed [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the [[2017 Birthday Honours]] for services to drama.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-40300916|title=In pictures: Entertainment and arts honours|author=Entertainment & Arts team|newspaper=[[BBC [[File:La Fura dels Bau - Dreams In Flight.jpg|thumb|250px|Dreams In Flight at the festival opening in 2007]] The '''Singapore Arts Festival''' ([[Simplified Chinese|Chinese]]: 新加坡艺术节) is an annual arts festival held in [[Singapore]]. Organised by the [[National Arts Council Singapore|National Arts Council]], it is one of the most significant events in the regional [[arts]] scene.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} The festival, usually held in mid-year for a stretch of one month, incorporates [[theatre arts]], [[dance]], [[music]] and [[visual arts]], among other possibilities. Besides local participants, approximately 70% of the events are put up by international artists.
Today, the Singapore Arts Festival is no longer managed by the National Arts Council. It has a new name and new direction under [http://www.sifa.sg Singapore International Festival of Arts] (SIFA), organised by Arts House Limited and commissioned by National Arts Council. In 2014 - 2017, the Festival Director for Singapore International Festival of Arts is Ong Keng Sen. He designed a two-part festival with a pre-festival of ideas [https://web.archive.org/web/20161231172823/https://sifa.sg/theopen/ The O.P.E.N]. (Open, Participate, Engage, Negotiate). The O.P.E.N. runs from June - July and thereafter followed by the main festival SIFA in August and September. Details on the new Singapore International Festival of Arts can be found at [http://www.sifa.sg www.sifa.sg].
== History == The Singapore Arts Festival started in 1977 as a national arts festival to celebrate local arts from the diverse communities in Singapore. Over the last three decades, the Festival has played a symbiotic and catalytic role in the development of the artistic and cultural life of Singapore. It has helped to transform the city’s cultural landscape, turning it into one of Asia’s major cultural capitals today. It has influenced local artists as well as increasing public awareness and demand for the arts, spawning new cultural platforms, events, and movements that help underpin the lively cultural scene in present Singapore. It was formed in 1999 when the existing Festival of Asian Performing Arts and the Festival of Arts were merged as an annual event.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_474_2005-01-24.html | title=Singapore dance festivals | accessdate=March 31, 2011 | publisher=[[National Library Board]] | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215091906/http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_474_2005-01-24.html | archivedate=December 15, 2011 | df= }}</ref>
== Local productions == In addition to international acts, Singaporean productions (some in collaboration with overseas partners) in previous Arts Festivals include [[ECNAD]]'s Missing In Tall Pillars (2002),<ref>[http://inkpot.com/theatre/02reviews/02revmisstallpill.html The Flying Inkpot Review] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008000548/http://inkpot.com/theatre/02reviews/02revmisstallpill.html |date=2008-10-08 }}</ref> [[Mark Chan]]'s Little Toys (2003), Opiume (2004) and Dreaming of Kuanyin Meeting Madonna (2007).
== Edition == * 2008 The Singapore Arts Festival focused on water in 2008, with both the opening and closing shows being performed on water.
The opening show of 2008, [[Water Fools]], was performed by the French group [[Ilotopie]]. It was held from 23–25 May at [[Boat Quay]]. The entire performance was performed in the [[Singapore River]]. The closing show, [[Hydro Sapiens]], was performed by [[The Lunatics]] from the [[Netherlands]]. It was held in [[Bedok Reservoir]] from 20–22 June.
*2010 The 2010s theme, Between You and Me, was all about getting closer to the arts. For the first time, the Festival will actively reach out to everyone through an outreach programme called com.mune. Together with a stellar showcase of international performances, the Festival will truly touch you in ways you never imagined possible.
*2011 Singapore Arts Festival 2011 will be held from 13 May to 5 June 2011 and its theme is 'I Want To Remember'. The opening show will be When a Gray Taiwanese Cow Stretched, by [[Ishinha]]. About the migration of people from the South Sea islands to South East Asia, Taiwan and Japan, it will be Singapore Arts Festival’s largest-ever outdoor performance at the [[Esplanade Park]].
==See also== *[[Singapore Biennale]] *[[Culture of Singapore]] *[[Music of Singapore]] *[[Dance in Singapore]] *[[Singapore Arts Street]]
==References== {{reflist}} [http://www.yoursingapore.com/content/traveller/en/browse/whats-on/festivals-and-events/singapore-arts-festival.html YourSingapore.com - Singapore Arts Festival]
==External links==

{{refimprove|date=January 2018}} '''Standoff distance''' is a security term that refers to measures to prevent unscreened and potentially threatening people and vehicles from approaching within a certain distance of a [[building]], [[car]], or other [[shelter (building)|shelter]], roadblock or other location, or to a person such as a law enforcement officer or VIP, or to a friendly area / location.<ref>[https://www.army.mil/article/63316/army_seeks_safe_soldier_solutions_through_research T'Jae Gibson, Army Research Laboratory (August 15, 2011) Army seeks safe Soldier solutions through research] * See also Gen. [[David G. Perkins]] ''Win in a complex world'', and other TRADOC doctrine</ref> ''See [[Power projection]], [[Identification friend or foe]], [[Display behavior]]''
Standoff distance may be ensured using fixed physical barriers such as fences or bollards; temporary placement of items to block access (e.g., using law enforcement vehicles or police tape to block a road or bridge); physical features other than barriers (these may appear innocuous, such as the [[White House]] lawn or adding an ornamental pond); armed guards or positions (e.g., a police [[sniper]] in [[Overwatch (military tactic)|overwatch]]); or deploying police officers with carbines such as an [[M4 carbine|M-4]], instead of just a service sidearm. When police officers have carbines the standoff distance is increased because an attacker who poses a threat can be fired upon from greater distances.
Standoff distance is used when a [[violence|violent]] [[criminal]] is in a fortified position, when [[hostage]]s are under armed threat from [[Kidnapping|kidnappers]], when a [[bomb]] is believed to have been placed, or when other unspecified dangers may be lurking. It is a measure of distance used by government, law enforcement, or military operatives handling the situation to protect their own agents and civilians from physical injury or death while the situation is resolved.
==Firearms==
When an armed and violent criminal is sheltered in a location not easily reachable by a [[tranquilizer]] round or [[disabling shot]] - or [[extreme prejudice]] ammunition, if authorized by mission leaders - police, military, and counterterrorism officers maintain distance (often out of the direct [[Sightline|line of sight]] and behind [[cover (military)|cover]]) while often using a [[megaphone]] to call for backup, the arrest of the subject, or to take him/her into custody. [[Sniper]] coverage is used often in these situations, and standard procedure for officers or operatives (or citizens taking part in a [[citizen's arrest]]) is to call for heavily [[armor]]ed backup while maintaining cover themselves. In the wake of active shooter scenarios, some law enforcement agencies have switched to moving in on the suspects, to prevent the gunmen from harming civilians. [[therapy|Therapeutic]] interventions or [[diplomacy|diplomatic]] techniques may be used to [[talk down]] the suspects or identified threats and assailants.
==Hostage situations==
In a hostage situation, the primary goal is the safe recovery of the hostages, who are usually held under threat of [[violence]] or other prolonged physical harm ([[starvation]], [[poison]]ing, [[bleeding]], [[illness]]) from [[kidnapping|kidnappers]]. Thus the situation is treated similarly to situations with other armed attackers under cover, but with even more caution. [[sniper]]s are often employed to attempt to provide leverage against the hostage-takers or to fire at the hostage takers if an imminent risk of harm to the hostages is identified.
Unless all kidnappers can be hit and killed by sniper gunfire almost simultaneously, generally [[extreme prejudice]] (e.g., shooting at gunmen)is not used as freely due to the danger of other kidnappers killing the hostages, as in the [[Munich massacre|1972 Munich]] example.
This is not true in [[lone wolf (terrorism)|lone wolf]] situations, where the hostage taker is often shot by a snipers with armor-piercing or wall-piercing ammunition if talk or negotiation resolution is impossible. In all situations the preferred method is to talk the kidnappers into releasing the hostages for [[ransom]] or otherwise talking them down using [[therapy|therapeutic]] or [[diplomacy|diplomatic]] techniques, to protect the safety of the hostages and, ideally, have the suspect surrender peacefully.
==Bombs== With bomb threats, the standoff distance used by law enforcement officers depends on the size and type of the bomb. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.slideshare.net/OFFSHC/offshc-gets-briefed-on-ieds |title=Office for Bombing Prevention: Improvised Explosive Device Awareness |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=www.slideshare.net |publisher=Homeland Security |access-date=15 January 2017 |quote=}} </ref> The smallest standoff distances, about 70 feet from the threat, are used for small [[pipe bomb]]s with about five pounds of explosives. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.slideshare.net/OFFSHC/offshc-gets-briefed-on-ieds |title=Office for Bombing Prevention: Improvised Explosive Device Awareness |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=www.slideshare.net |publisher=Homeland Security |access-date=15 January 2017 |quote=}} </ref> A human suicide bomber with about 20 pounds of explosives strapped to his/her body has a standoff distance of 110 feet.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.slideshare.net/OFFSHC/offshc-gets-briefed-on-ieds |title=Office for Bombing Prevention: Improvised Explosive Device Awareness |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=www.slideshare.net |publisher=Homeland Security |access-date=15 January 2017 |quote=}} </ref> A briefcase or suitcase bomb with about 50 pounds of explosives has a 150 foot standoff distance.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.slideshare.net/OFFSHC/offshc-gets-briefed-on-ieds |title=Office for Bombing Prevention: Improvised Explosive Device Awareness |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=www.slideshare.net |publisher=Homeland Security |access-date=15 January 2017 |quote=}} </ref> Larger car bombs or truck bombs have a much larger standoff distance, as the blast radius is bigger. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.slideshare.net/OFFSHC/offshc-gets-briefed-on-ieds |title=Office for Bombing Prevention: Improvised Explosive Device Awareness |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=www.slideshare.net |publisher=Homeland Security |access-date=15 January 2017 |quote=}} </ref> A car bomb with a 500 pound bomb has a 320 foot standoff distance.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.slideshare.net/OFFSHC/offshc-gets-briefed-on-ieds |title=Office for Bombing Prevention: Improvised Explosive Device Awareness |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=www.slideshare.net |publisher=Homeland Security |access-date=15 January 2017 |quote=}} </ref> A small delivery truck-based truck bomb with a 1,000 pound bomb has a 640 foot standoff distance.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.slideshare.net/OFFSHC/offshc-gets-briefed-on-ieds |title=Office for Bombing Prevention: Improvised Explosive Device Awareness |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=www.slideshare.net |publisher=Homeland Security |access-date=15 January 2017 |quote=}} </ref> A huge 18-wheeler truck-sized truck bomb with over 60,000 pounds of explosives has a 1,570 foot standoff distance.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.slideshare.net/OFFSHC/offshc-gets-briefed-on-ieds |title=Office for Bombing Prevention: Improvised Explosive Device Awareness |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=www.slideshare.net |publisher=Homeland Security |access-date=15 January 2017 |quote=}} </ref>
Standoff distance is also intended to deter terrorists from using [[car bomb]]s by making it more difficult for them to cause catastrophic damage. In the wake of the [[Oklahoma City bombing]], many high-risk federal buildings began enforcing standoff distances. It is based on the concept that a blast shock load is essentially a [[high-pressure front]] that moves out radially and decays very quickly<ref>http://govtsecurity.com/mag/blastresistant_facilities_even/</ref> - because blast falloff is thus often more [[exponentiation|exponential]] than [[linear]] (indeed [[Vector (geometric)|radial]] - any given explosive must cover a circular-shaped area but blast power generally only increases linearly with explosive strength){{citation needed|date=December 2014}}, any standoff distance helps increases survival chances for passersby and minimizes danger, though [[Fragmentation (weaponry)|shrapnel]] mitigates this effect if present.
Hydraulic [[roadblock]]s (sometimes wedge-shaped), or [[bollard]]s can be raised to block approaching vehicles; these can be designed to prevent even a heavy, fast-moving truck from getting through. [[Jersey barrier]]s and concrete planters filled with dirt have also been used to maintain separation between screened and unscreened traffic. Certain infrastructure at risk of terrorist attack, such as bridges, may not be well-suited to standoff distances since their purpose is for traffic to travel along them.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * http://www.asisonline.org/councils/BlastResistantStandards_1.pdf

[[File:Lion scarf wiki.jpg|thumb|right|In February 2007 [[Stitch and Bitch London]] presented the London Lion Scarf around the necks of the [[Trafalgar Square]] Lions in central London. They raised over £2500 for cancer research.]] '''Stitch 'n Bitch''' is a name that has been used to refer to social knitting groups since at least World War II.<ref name="idle">{{cite book |author=Macdonald, Anne L. |title=No Idle Hands: The Social History of American Knitting |publisher=Ballantine Books |location=[New York |year=1988 |pages=302 |isbn=0-345-33906-1 |url=http://www.cogknition.org/stitchnbitchdb/reference.php?id=73_0_4_0_M}}</ref> Before the slang term “Stitch ‘n Bitch” was used, groups of women in the 1940s would join to knit and talk in organized Stitch and Bitch clubs. The term was further used in the 1980s as part of the book ''Social History of American Knitting'' by Anne Macdonald.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brightman|first=Emilee|title=Crafty Ladies: Local knitting group not what you would expect|url=http://www.lakewoodobserver.com/read/2009/01/27/crafty-ladies-local-knitting-group-not|publisher=The Lakewood Observer|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> It is partly due to the book's success that the modern day Stitch n' Bitch knitting groups have emerged in cities around the world. The groups, mainly women, meet to knit, stitch and talk. Typically, attendees knit, though others crochet (they are called 'Happy Hookers'), and still others engage in cross-stitching, embroidery, and other needlecraft. Nowadays, the groups have been analyzed by scholars as expressions of resistance to major political, social and technological change in Western societies. However, political discussion is not unusual at these events, and at least some participants are proponents of progressive, liberal, and/or leftist social and political change. Furthermore, the term Stitch ‘n' Bitch is now used by women from across the globe to connect with others in the virtual space seeing as the term has re-emerged in a world where the public sphere is the cyberspace.
With over 1460 registered Stitch ‘n Bitch groups in 289 cities worldwide, the social knitting movement has demarked itself as a popular social gathering for avid knitters.<ref>{{cite web|last=Stitch 'n Bitch|title=Stitch 'n Bitch Find a knitting group or start your own|url=http://stitchnbitch.org/|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref>
==Knitting groups== ''Stitch 'n Bitch'' is a name used by knitting groups that meet on a weekly or monthly basis at locations throughout the world. This use of the term originates as early as the [[Second World War]].<ref name="idle" /><ref name="telegraph">{{cite news | last = Elsworth | first = Catherine | title = It's getting bitchy in knitting circles | work = Telegraph.co.uk | date = 2006-11-02 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/02/11/wknit11.xml&sSheet=/news/2006/02/11/ixworld.html | accessdate = 2007-05-25 }}</ref> In 1999, Debbie Stoller started a Stitch 'n Bitch group in NYC's East Village, which was open to anyone who wanted to come to knit along or learn to knit.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} In 2000, she wrote about her groups in ''BUST'' magazine, of which she is the editor-in-chief. Brenda Janish read the article and started the Chicago Stitch 'n Bitch group.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} That article inspired Vickie Howell to start the Los Angeles Stitch 'n Bitch group and later the Austin Stitch 'n Bitch group.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2003/nov/20/news/wk-alt20 "Sisters of the Stitch", L.A. Times, Nov. 20, 2003]</ref> Like Stoller's original group, today's Stitch 'n Bitch clubs are generally casual groups of knitters who meet in public spaces such as bars or cafes for socializing and sharing knitting advice. These groups are free or small fee required memberships and open to the public, and are listed in a directory of worldwide knitting groups that was started by Janish and today is maintained by Stoller: Official Home of Stitch 'n Bitch. As of 2010, the site lists over 700 such groups.
==Book series and legal actions== [[File:Stitch 'n Bitch Book Cover.jpg|thumb|200px|left|The cover of the first book in the series of knitting books by Debbie Stoller, ''Stitch 'n Bitch: The Knitter's Handbook''.]]
A book series by Debbie Stoller, includes ''Stitch 'n Bitch" : The Knitter's Handbook'', ''Stitch 'n Bitch Crochet: The Happy Hooker,'' and other titles.<ref>{{cite book|last=Stoller|first=Debbie|title=Stitch 'n Bitch Crochet: The Happy Hooker|year=2006|publisher=Workman Publishing Company, Inc.|location=New York|pages=1–283}}</ref> From 2005 to 2008, Stitch 'n Bitch was the focus of a [[trademark]] dispute. In June 2005, the company [[Sew Fast Sew Easy]] filed a trademark application for ''Stitch & Bitch'' to designate a line of knitting and sewing supplies. As of 2007 this application was suspended.<ref name="S&B">{{cite journal |author=United States Patent and Trademark Office | title = Serial Number: 78641350 | publisher = Trademark Trial and Appeal Board Inquiry System | date = November 28, 2007 | url = http://tarr.uspto.gov/servlet/tarr?regser=serial&entry=78641350&action=Request+Status |accessdate=2007-11-28}}</ref> In fall 2005, due to letters claiming [[trademark infringement]] from Sew Fast/Sew Easy's lawyers, knitting groups that had accounts with [[CafePress]] were forced to remove all items featuring the phrase "Stitch 'n Bitch". Local groups that communicated with each other through [[Yahoo! Groups]] were similarly forced to remove "Stitch 'n Bitch" from the name and description of their group.<ref name="vogue">{{cite journal | last = Petrovsky | first = Lesley | title = Tempest in a Tea Cozy | journal = Vogue Knitting | date = Fall 2006 | url = http://freetostitchfreetobitch.org/pdfs/vogueknit.gif | accessdate = 2007-05-26 }}</ref> Some groups were deleted, but most groups were able to change their name on Yahoo! to SNB.<ref name="knit">{{cite journal | last = Krementz | first = Cheryl | title = Stitch & Bitch Slap | journal = Knit.1 | date = Summer 2006 | url = http://freetostitchfreetobitch.org/pdfs/knit1.gif | accessdate = 2007-05-26 }}</ref> In 2008, Sew Fast Sew Easy and Debbie Stoller reached a settlement in which Debbie Stoller retained the use of the mark in knitting while Sew Fast Sew Easy retains the use for sewing. Since then all four of Stoller's trademarks have now been registered. The Sew Fast Sew Easy store closed in 2012.
== Social implications == In recent years, the Stitch ‘n Bitch movement has been considered as a means of reclaiming women’s domestic work in feminist circles. Not only have groups officially been formed through website use, but groups of women on university campuses have also followed the trends in order to resist the taboo representation of the traditional woman.
Dr. Beth Ann Pentney, writing in Thirdspace journal, credited Stoller's publications with the rise of feminist knitting. Stoller introduced this approach to feminism to merge political involvement with a women’s community-building activity set in a Do-It-Yourself culture.<ref name="Pentney 2008">{{cite journal|last=Pentney|first=Beth Ann|title=Feminism, Activism, and Knitting: Are the Fibre Arts a Viable Mode for Feminist Political Action?|journal=Third Space: a journal of feminist theory and culture|date=Summer 2008|volume=8|issue=1|url=http://www.thirdspace.ca/journal/article/viewArticle/pentney/210|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> As a response to Stoller, much scrutiny on the effectiveness of the reclamation of domestic arts as a political feminist act has been done. Some say that the reason of the reintroduction of knitting in modern social gatherings is mainly due to the increase in the search for individualism and the anti-consumerism attitude of our generation.<ref name="Pentney 2008"/> With this said, it is important to denote the implication of technologies in the emergence of a “fabriculture” based on the reclamation of domestic arts and crafts.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bratich|first=Jack|author2=Brush, Heidi M. |title=Fabricating activism: Craft-Work, Popular Culture, Gender|journal=Utopian Studies|date=27 November 2011|volume=22|issue=2|pages=233–260|url=https://www.academia.edu/1117424/Fabricating_Activism_Craft-Work_Popular_Culture_Gender|accessdate=19 March 2013|doi=10.5325/utopianstudies.22.2.0233}}</ref> With the internet accessibility of online information and tips and tricks for knitters and crocheters, the traditionally personal practice of knitting can now be shared easily among strangers, and is open to public discussion and new ideas. These webs of knitters worldwide find affinities via a very modern technology opposing the traditional DIY nature of knitting.
==Further reading== * {{cite book |author=Debbie Stoller |title=Stitch 'n Bitch: the knitter's handbook |publisher=Workman Publishing Company |location=New York |year=2003 |isbn=0-7611-2818-2 }} * {{cite book |author=Debbie Stoller |title=Stitch 'n Bitch Nation |publisher=Workman Publishing Company |location=New York |year=2004 |isbn=0-7611-3590-1 }} * {{cite book |author=Debbie Stoller|title=Stitch 'n Bitch Crochet: The Happy Hooker |publisher=Workman Publishing Company |location=New York |year=2006 |isbn=978-0-7611-3985-0 }} * {{cite book |author=Debbie Stoller|title=Son of Stitch 'n Bitch: 45 Projects to Knit and Crochet for Men (Paperback)|publisher=Workman Publishing Company |location=New York |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-7611-4617-9 }}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * Knitting groups: [http://www.stitchnbitch.org/snb_groups.htm Stitch 'n Bitch Groups Worldwide] - Contact information for local groups worldwide * Debbie Stoller: [http://www.knithappens.com/ Stitch 'n Bitch promotional web site] - Book series * Interactive [http://www.inkling.com/store/book/stitch-n-bitch-knitters-handbook-debbie-stoller-1st/ Stitch 'n Bitch: The Knitter's Handbook] - on Inkling
